ref.mixed-citation: Howard Erskine-Hill, Poetry of Opposition and Revolution: Dry den to Wordsworth (Oxford, 1996), p. 40.
Dry den and the Traces of Classical Rome (Oxford, 1999), p. 149.
Of Dramatic Poesy and Other Critical Essays, edited by George Watson, 2 vols (London, 1962;
'Essays'), II, 66.
'Criticism and the Meanings of "Theory"', British Journal of Aesthetics, 37 (1997), 377-85.
Robert D. Hume, in Dryden's Criticism (Ithaca, 1970),
'A Chronological List of Dryden's Major Critical Essays' which admits the 'Life of Plutarch'. Edward Pechter, in Dryden's Classical Theory of Literature (Cambridge, 1975),
Collingwood's 'History as Re-Enactment of Past Experience', in The Idea of History, edited by Jan van der Dussen (Oxford, 1994), pp. 282-302.
Paul Ricoeur, 'The Reality of the Past', in Time and Narrative, translated by Kathleen Blarney and David Pellauer, 3 vols (Chicago, 1088), III, 142-56.
Dryden, Of the Pythagorean Philosophy, 262-3; Kinsley, IV, 1724.
The Cambridge History of Literary Criticism, IV: The Eighteenth Century, edited by H. B. Nisbet and Claude Rawson (Cambridge, 1997), p. xviii.
Shakespeare's Language (London, 2000), p. viii.
'A Dryden Allusion to Rymer's Rapin', N&Q, 221 (1976), 554-
J. W. H. Atkins, English Literary Criticism: Seventeenth and Eighteenth Centuries (London, 195 1), p. 72.
John Davies's rendering, Observations on the Poems of Homer and Vergil (London, 1672).
The Twickenham Edition of the Poems of Alexander Pope, VII:
The Iliad of Homer, Books I-IX, edited by Maynard Mack (New Haven, 1967), pp. 3-25, especially pp. 4-5.
The Yale Edition of the Works of Samuel Johnson, VII: Johnson on Shakespeare, edited by Arthur Sherbo (New Haven, 1968), p. 84.
'Johnson's Life of Pope and Pope's Preface to the Iliad1, N&Q225 (1980), 50.
The Just and the Lively: The Literary Criticism of John Dryden (New York, 1999) of the 'theoretical' and the 'practical' as the two principal tasks of Dry den's work as a critic (p. 242).
R. S. Crane, 'On Writing the History of Criticism in England, 1650-1800' (1953), in The Idea of the Humanities and Other Essays Critical and Historical, 2 vols (Chicago, 1967), II, 174-5.
The Idea of History (n. 6), p. 226:
Hans-Georg Gadamer, 'The Elevation of the Historicity of Understanding', Truth and Method, translation revised by Joel Weinsheimer and Donald G. Marshall, second edition (London, 1989), pp. 289-90.
Rymer's translation of Rapin's Reflexions sur la poetique d'Aristote was published in 1674.
